arguments.text: Thirty participants underwent 24‑hour total sleep deprivation followed by a computerized n‑back working memory test. Accuracy declined by 15% compared with rested baseline (p<0.01).
Participants were limited to 4 h sleep per night for five nights. On the Stroop and task‑switching tests, reaction times increased by 200 ms and error rates rose by 12% (p<0.05).
After 36 h of continuous wakefulness, participants showed a 30% increase in lapses on the Psychomotor Vigilance Task and chose riskier options in a gambling task (p<0.01).

messages.content: Research consistently demonstrates that both acute and chronic sleep loss impair key aspects of cognition. A single night of total deprivation reduces working‑memory accuracy by roughly 15%, while repeated restriction to four hours per night prolongs reaction times and raises error rates on executive‑function tasks. Extended wakefulness (36 hours) further degrades sustained attention, increasing performance lapses by 30% and promoting riskier decision‑making. Collectively, these findings underscore sleep’s vital role in maintaining optimal memory, executive control, and attentional stability.
